head.title: Promotion Effect of Modified Ni/C by La–Ce Oxide for Durable Hydrogen Evolution Reaction | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Promotion Effect of Modified Ni/C by La–Ce Oxide for Durable Hydrogen Evolution Reaction

Improved durability of transition metal electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is increasing in importance for commercialized, eco-friendly hydrogen production. In this study we report improved electrocatalytic activity and durability of Ni, which has potential in an alkaline atmosphere for HER via the interaction between Ni and La–Ce oxide (LCO). Excellent HER durability was guaranteed by the interaction between Ni and LCO, owing to changes in the electronic structure, improved activity, and durability of anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE). The LCO promoted Ni nanoparticle deposition on carbon black (Ni-LCO/C); this showed a lower overpotential of 114 mVRHE at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 and higher long-term stability compared to Ni/C. This study demonstrates that the combination of Ni and LCO is a powerful way to improve the efficiency of AEMWE. This can be applied to high-efficiency hydrogen production.

a.title: Go to ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

img.alt: Go to ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

div.p:
Improved durability of transition metal electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is increasing in importance for commercialized, eco-friendly hydrogen production. In this study we report improved electrocatalytic activity and durability of Ni, which has potential in an alkaline atmosphere for HER via the interaction between Ni and La–Ce oxide (LCO). Excellent HER durability was guaranteed by the interaction between Ni and LCO, owing to changes in the electronic structure, improved activity, and durability of anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE). The LCO promoted Ni nanoparticle deposition on carbon black (Ni-LCO/C); this showed a lower overpotential of 114 mV
RHE
at a current density of 10 mA cm
–2
and higher long-term stability compared to Ni/C. This study demonstrates that the combination of Ni and LCO is a powerful way to improve the efficiency of AEMWE. This can be applied to high-efficiency hydrogen production.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: The interaction of La−Ce oxide (LCO) and Ni/C dramatically improves electrocatalytic performance and durability in an alkaline atmosphere due to the occurrence of electronic modification.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) method can be stacked using an electrolyte membrane and can produce high-purity hydrogen with high-pressure. In addition, it is a next-generation water electrolysis technology that has recently attracted attention for its advantage of being able to use an inexpensive nonprecious metal catalyst due to an alkaline atmosphere.
(1−5)
However, the low efficiency due to the use of nonprecious metal catalysts is an area to be improved. Recently, in order to solve this problem, the development of high performance nonprecious metal catalysts has been actively developed.

Among them, transition metal-based electrocatalysts (TMEs) are accelerating the commercialization of alkali-based water electrolysis by improving performance via various means and at a lower cost compared to platinum group catalysts.
(6,7)
However, development in the field of TMEs for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is impeded by deterioration of the electrocatalyst in an alkaline atmosphere
(8)
because TMEs are generally ionized in a highly concentrated alkaline atmosphere.
(9−12)
Moreover, continuous anion exchange occurring via the anion exchange membrane (AEM) leads to a high pH in the vicinity of the AEM, which accelerates the deterioration of the TMEs.
(13)
Designing a TME that is stable in a highly alkaline atmosphere is crucial for the development of a high-efficiency electrolysis system. Despite numerous reports of TMEs with excellent electrochemical activity in an alkaline atmosphere for HER,
(14−17)
some cases report durability problems resulting from the instability of TMEs in an alkaline atmosphere.
(18)
Ni has been recognized for a catalytic activity that can replace platinum group metals, and various studies have been conducted to improve the intrinsic durability of Ni-based catalysts.
(19−21)
A representative study was conducted to improve the activity and durability of the catalyst by synthesizing Ni and other transition metals.
(19)
La and Ce of the lanthanide series have been studied as cocatalysts for Ni and play an important role in increasing the number of active sites and enhancing intrinsic catalytic activity.
(22−28)
Despite the reported synergistic effects of lanthanide and Ni, the development of catalysts for application to practical water electrolysis systems is a challenge that requires new approaches.

We report an improvement in the electrocatalytic activity and durability of HER in an alkaline media via the interaction of Ni and La–Ce oxide (denoted as LCO) as cocatalyst. The study included not only an inquiry into the synthesis and practical application of nanosized Ni and LCO on carbon support but also insights into the role of the cocatalyst. The following notable results were obtained from our study, which provided important insights for improving the durability and intrinsic activity of Ni catalysts using LCO.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Ni/C (nickel electrocatalyst supported by carbon) and Ni-LCO/C were synthesized by the solvothermal method (
Figure
1
a). The Ni/C exhibited a Ni content of 30 wt. %, and in the case of Ni-LCO/C, 20 wt. % of LCO was added by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) (
Figure S1a
). Also, the BET surface area of Ni-LCO/C showed a low value due to the increase of the loading amount supported on the carbon (
Figure S1b
). It is obvious from the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) results that synthesized electrocatalysts are uniformly dispersed on the carbon support (
Figure
1
b). The average particle size of the Ni-LCO/C (5.34 nm in
Figure
1
b and
Figure S2
) can be seen to be smaller than that of Ni/C (11.2 nm in
Figure
3
a and
Figure S2
). It is possible to distinguish between Ni and LCO particles on the carbon support in the high-resolution TEM image (
Figure
1
c). Ni particles (111) with a size of about 5 nm are surrounded by LCO particles (111) or (200). LCO is preferentially placed on the carbon so that Ni should be loaded in a small space, thus reducing the size of Ni particles. The selected-area electron diffraction pattern of the Ni-LCO/C confirms the presence of Ni and Ni oxide (
Figure
1
d).
(29)
The broad ring around the center spot corresponds to the C (002),
(30)
and its outline (yellow dashed line) corresponds to the LCO (111).
(31,32)
TEM-energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy mapping images confirm (
Figure S3
) that of the elements Ni, Ce, La, and O for the Ni-LCO/C. It is observed that Ni is clearly formed as particles, while Ce and La exist as a complex oxide, so they appear almost overlapping. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C (
Figure
1
e) shows (111), (200), and (220) for the face centered cubic Ni phase (ICSD No. 005-3808) and (111), (002), (022), and (113) for La–Ce oxide, which is identified as La
0.44
Ce
0.56
O (ICSD No. 007-7910).
(31,32)
The peak around 25° indicates the (002) of carbon.
Figure S4a
shows the difference between XRD patterns of La oxide/C, Ce oxide/C, and La–Ce oxide/C. The peaks associated with La oxide are hardly observed in La
2
O
3
/C, which may be due to poor precipitation of La
2
O
3
on the carbon independently. By contrast, the peak associated with Ce oxide can be easily identified in CeO
2
/C. Considering that the peak of Ce oxide decreases in LCO/C, it is deduced that La and Ce formed an oxide. In addition, the peak of Ni (111) in the Ni-LCO/C shifts to the low angle (Δ0.5°) compared to that of Ni/C. It seems obvious that Ni and LCO partly formed an heterostructure (
Figure S4b
).

div.p: Figure 1. (a) Synthesis procedure and structural model of Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C by coprecipitation and solvothermal. (b) TEM image of synthesized Ni-LCO/C. (c) Lattice resolved TEM image from part b. (d) Associated SAED pattern image of Ni-LCO/C. (e) XRD patterns of synthesized Ni/C (black line) and Ni-LCO/C (red line).

div.div:
The electrocatalytic properties of the electrocatalysts were investigated in 1 M KOH at 25 °C to measure the HER activity.
Figure
2
a shows the electrocatalytic activity of Ni/C, Ni-LCO/C, and commercial Ni/C (c-Ni/C) for comparison. c-Ni/C has the onset potentials of 225 mV
RHE
(vs RHE, reversible hydrogen electrode) at a current density of 10 mA cm
–2
. The overpotentials of the synthesized Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C are 132 mV
RHE
and 114 mV
RHE
at 10 mA cm
–2
, respectively, which are both lower than those of c-Ni/C. Ni-LCO/C may have an increased active area due to a smaller particle size of Ni compared to Ni/C and c-Ni/C (
Figures S2 and S5
).
Figure S6
present the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of the double-layer capacitance determined from cyclic voltammetry curves recorded at different scan rates in the nonfaradaic region of Ni/C, Ni-LCO/C, and c-Ni/C. c-Ni/C has an ECSA of 4.88 mF cm
–2
, while Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C have ECSAs of 6.35 and 8.05 mF cm
–2
, respectively. The increase in the ECSA of Ni-LCO/C was a significant effect of the decrease in the size of Ni particles due to the preferential placement of LCO.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) LSV polarization curves for HER at 2 mV s
–1
. (b) Corresponding Tafel plot of c-Ni/C (gray line), Ni/C (black line), and Ni-LCO/C (red line) derived from the polarization curve of part a. (c) Galvanostatic curves of c-Ni/C, Ni/C, and Ni-LCO/C under constant currents of −10, −20, and −40 mA cm
–2
for a durability test in 1 M KOH solution.

div.div:
The promotion effect of Ni-LCO/C electrocatalyst is understood with the two mechanisms for HER, which are the Volmer–Heyrovsky and Volmer–Tafel pathways.
(33)
(1)
(2)
(3)

The first step of both pathways is the Volmer step,
eq 1
. A proton is adsorbed on a surface dehydrogenated oxygen species aided by an electron. The Volmer step is a sluggish process when compared with the Heyrovsky and Tafel steps as indicated by their Tafel slopes. Larger Tafel slopes result from slower kinetics, and a larger potential difference is required to achieve a fixed current difference. The Tafel slope of the Volmer step is known to be 120 mV dec
–1
, which is much larger than 40 mV dec
–1
for the Heyrovsky step and 30 mV dec
–1
for the Tafel step.
(34)
The Tafel plots derived from each polarization curve are shown in
Figure
2
b; these were used to analyze the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalyst. The Tafel slopes of Ni/C, Ni-LCO/C, and c-Ni/C are 98.2, 72.7, and 145.9 mV dec
–1
, respectively, and their hydrogen evolution pathway largely corresponds to the Volmer–Heyrovsky step.
(34)
In general, Ni, which is favorable for hydrogen adsorption owing to abundant electrons in the d-band, increases the adsorbed hydrogen (H
ads
) on the Ni surface as the reaction continues, resulting in slowing down the HER process.
(35)
By contrast, LCO, which has abundant half-filled and empty d orbitals, can desorb the H
ads
on Ni, thereby improving the rate of the HER process. The hydrogen adsorption reaction (Volmer step) occurred effectively on the Ni surface by the continuous desorbing of H
ads
by LCO during the HER process. That is, The HO–H bonds can be efficiently cleaved at the interface of Ni-LCO/C, resulting in the formation of OH
–
on LCO and H
ads
on the neighboring Ni site. The as-derived H
ads
are then proficiently converted to H
2
by the Ni. Thus, a faster HER kinetics was observed on the Ni-LCO/C interface. Also, electrocatalysts should have reliable durability as well as high-efficiency catalytic activity to be applied to practical AEMWE systems.
Figure
2
c shows the durability of each electrocatalyst evaluated by constant current densities of −10, −20, and −40 mA cm
–2
, respectively. Ni-LCO/C has significantly superior durability compared to Ni/C and c-Ni/C in terms of the change of current density.
Figure S7
shows the LSV curves of Ni-LCO/C and Ni/C after CV scanning. While Ni-LCO/C showed a potential difference of 11 mV at 10 mA/cm
2
during 500 cycles, Ni/C showed a difference of 31 mV. This result supports that Ni-LCO/C indicates better durability than in the case of the absence of LCO. The LCO prevents the active site of Ni from poisoning of the OH
–
when the HO–H bond is cleaved at the Ni-LCO/C interface.
(36)
The heterostructure of Ni with the LCO electrocatalyst induced a facile electron transfer from carbon support to Ni than Ni/C, leading to the strong interaction between the substrate and the metal electrocatalyst particles.
(37)
For this reason, it is considered that the durability is improved, and it was confirmed that the dissolution of Ni was also reduced after the durability test (
Figure S8b,c
). In addition, it was confirmed that the structure of Ni-LCO/C was well maintained after the durability test (
Figure S8a
).

Figure
3
a showed the TEM images before and after the durability test by an agglomeration and detachment of the electrocatalyst with and without LCO. After a durability test, the Ni particles of Ni/C are larger than those of the Ni-LCO/C, and a number of Ni-detached carbons are observed in Ni/C. The catalytic degradation mechanism of Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C can be explained similarly to the conventional Pt/C degradation mechanism (
Figure S9
).
(38)
The formation of a heterostructure of LCO and Ni can help prevent detachment of the Ni particles from the carbon. LCO, which is not directly involved in hydrogen evolution, can maintain a more stable bond with carbon, and Ni may eventually bond more strongly to carbon due to the formation of the heterostructure with LCO. In addition, LCO acts as a barrier, preventing the migration of Ni particles by swelling of the binder, thereby reducing the aggregation of Ni particles.

div.p: Figure 3. (a) TEM images of Ni-LCO/C (above images) and Ni/C (below images) before and after the durability test. (b) XPS Ni 2p spectra of Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C before the durability test. (c) XANES spectra recorded at the Ni K edge of Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C by a synchrotron light source.

div.div:
Figure
3
b presents the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of Ni 2p
3/2
states of Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C. The peaks were distinguished between the Ni 2p
3/2
peak around 853 eV corresponding to Ni
0
and the Ni 2p
3/2
peak around 855 and 857 eV, which could be assigned to Ni
2+
states as NiO or Ni(OH)
2
.
(39−42)
Significantly, the shift of the binding energy to lower energies by 0.9 eV appears in Ni-LCO/C compared to the Ni/C. The negative shift of Ni
0
in binding energy represents the electron transfer from carbon support to nickel occurring more in Ni-LCO/C than Ni/C. To examine the changes in electron transport in more detail, the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) results of the Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C are shown in
Figure
3
c. The Ni k-edge spectra of the Ni/C and Ni-LCO/C shows a characteristic white line peak at 8350 eV, and the absorption peak starts at approximately 8331 eV.
(43,44)
The white line intensity of Ni-LCO/C was lower than that of Ni/C, suggesting a change in the electronic structure around the Ni of Ni-LCO/C.
(43,45)
This result presents that the d-band vacancies in Ni decrease with the presence of the cocatalyst, LCO. The d-band vacancies are probably filled with electrons donated from LCO with carbon support. It can be confirmed that the heterostructure of the Ni-LCO/C electrocatalyst improved the electrocatalytic performance by inducing a strong interaction between the substrate and the catalyst particles by easily inducing electron transfer to Ni rather than Ni/C on the carbon support.

In order to confirm the possibility of the synthesized electrocatalyst in the water electrolysis system, AEMWE single cell was fabricated (
Figure
4
a and
Figure S10
). The performance of the cell with Ni-LCO/C as the cathode was no significant difference in the onset voltages, but Ni-LCO/C shows high current density better than that with Ni/C at high voltage region (
Figure
4
b). In addition, Ni-LCO/C shows a fairly stable voltage variation compared to Ni/C in the durability test at a constant current density of 500 mA cm
–2
(
Figure
4
c). The difference between the initial voltage (1.895 V
cell
) and the final voltage (1.923 V
cell
) is approximately 28 mV
cell
for Ni-LCO/C. This is because the increase in the stability of Ni-LCO/C due to the interaction between Ni and LCO has an effect on the improvement of durability. By contrast, c-Ni/C has a relatively high onset voltage (∼1.7 V
cell
) compared to the synthesized catalysts, and it has a slope similar to that of Ni/C, with increasing voltage. The voltage of c-Ni/C stabilizes after 30 h in the durability test, but the required voltage for 500 mA cm
–2
is almost 2 V
cell
or more, which lowers the efficiency of the cell. The cell with Ni-LCO/C as the cathode has a high level of performance among the reported AEMWE cells using only nonprecious metals or oxides (
Table S1
).

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Photograph of hydrogen bubbles evolved in the AEMWE cell. (b) Polarization curves of the AEMWE cell using Ni/C, Ni-LCO/C, and c-Ni/C as cathode (1.5 mg cm
–2
) and Cu
0.5
Co
2.5
O
4
(10 mg cm
–2
) as the anode in 0.1 M KOH at 45 °C. (c) The durability test of voltage–time plots for the AEMWE single cell at 500 mA cm
–2
for 100 h in 0.1 M KOH at 45 °C.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In conclusion, we present the improvement in the activity and durability of the AEMWE cell achieved via an interaction between Ni and LCO. The degradation of Ni which is an active electrocatalyst for HER was significantly reduced due to the role of LCO as a cocatalyst and the change in the electronic structure. LCO is preferentially placed on the carbon surface, reducing the size of Ni particles. In addition, LCO acts as an electron donor to prevent degradation of the catalyst by forming heterostructure with Ni. The Ni-LCO/C recorded an overpotential of 114 mV
RHE
at −10 mA cm
–2
in 1 M KOH with a three electrode system. Furthermore, the AEMWE cell using Ni-LCO/C as a cathode recorded a current density of 450 mA cm
–2
at 1.8 V
cell
at 45 °C with 0.1 M KOH and was more stable than that using Ni/C cathode without LCO.

Ni-based electrocatalysts for replacement of precious metal electrocatalyst, the cathode materials of anion exchange membrane water electrolyzer (AEMWE), are seriously unstable and low activity at hydrogen prodn. conditions. This study develops a high-performance, durable non-precious metal electrocatalyst for AEMWE, which show improved activity and durability. First, Ni/C was alloyed with Co and supported on carbon cloth coated with microporous carbon layer to improve the electrocatalytic activity of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalyst; then, oxide (Ni/Co-O) was locally formed on the synthesized NiCo/C to increase its activity and durability. Specifically, this oxide increased the coverage of OH- ions, formed hydrogen spillover channels, and promoted the HER. Further, its improved electrochem. durability was attributed to the high bond dissocn. energy of the metal oxide. The electrocatalyst was also evaluated as the cathode in single-cell (1-cell) and stack cell (5-cell) AEMWE systems to demonstrate that this superior performance would translate to the com. scale.

The application of electrocatalysts with high activity to a practical water electrolysis cell is a crucial challenge for the prodn. of pure hydrogen and commercialization of the water electrolyzer. Herein, a nanosized Cu0.5Co2.5O4 catalyst synthesized by co-pptn. by adjusting pH is applied to the anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) cell as an anode, which is demonstrated to have higher efficiency and stability than noble metal-based anodes. In the d. functional theory study, the electronic structure of Co modified by Cu in the Co3O4 lattice leads to an optimal adsorption strength, resulting in a free energy diagram in which the potential of Cu0.5Co2.5O4 (1.756 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) is more thermodynamically favorable than that of Co3O4 (1.951 V vs. RHE). Uniquely nanostructured CuCo2O4 is presented as an electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reactions (OER). CuCo2O4 particles in a chestnut-burr-like shape (CCO*, where * = chestnut burr) were hydrothermally synthesized around fibers of Ni foam substrates as current collectors. Chestnut burrs 4μm on av. had thorns consisting of less than five threads. Each thread was made of a consecutive array of nanobeads less than 10 nm. Nanovoids or nanopores were found between nanobeads. The chestnut-burr structure of CCO* allowed IrO2-overwhelming OER activity. By using the hierarchically nanostructured electrocatalyst directly grown on current collectors without binders and conducting agents, high performances of anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis was demonstrated. Three merits of the electrode architecture were emphasized. First, mass transfer pathways for reactants and products were secured in a microscale between thorns and in a nanoscale between nanobeads. Second, more active sites were exposed to electrolytes in the hierarchical structure. Third, direct growth of active materials on conductive substrates improved adhesion and elec. conduction. The unique structure of directly grown CCO* (CCO*, where* = chestnut burr) providing binder-free and conducting agent-free benefits and allowing exceptionally high loading on substrates dramatically enhanced electroactivities of OER for efficient electrolysis.

The innovation in highly efficient, stable, and economical bifunctional overall water-splitting electrocatalysts is crit. in developing sustainable energy, but it remains challenging. In this research, an unsophisticated method is developed to synthesize hybrid nanoparticles (FeN0.023/Mo2C/C) uniformly dispersed in nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets. The two active components FeN0.023 and Mo2C are coupled to form an FeN0.023/Mo2C/C heterostructure being a highly efficient electrocatalyst, which gives low overpotentials of 227/76 mV for OER/HER at 10 mA cm-2 c.d. The alk.-electrolyzer with FeN0.023/Mo2C/C as the anode-cathode catalyst needs merely 1.55 V to reach 10 mA cm-2 and can maintain a stable state for a min. of 10 h. This research gives a simple effective resoln. in designing affordable and useful overall water-splitting electrocatalysts.

Employing a low-cost and highly efficient electrocatalyst to replace Pt-based catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) has attracted increasing interest in renewable energy research. Earth-abundant transition metals such as Fe, Co and Ni have been investigated as promising alternatives in alk. electrolytes. However, these non-precious-metal catalysts are not stable in acids, excluding their application in the acidic solid polymer electrolyte (SPE). Herein, we report a strategy to encapsulate 3d transition metals Fe, Co and the FeCo alloy into nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and investigated their HER activity in acidic electrolytes. The optimized catalysts exhibited long-term durability and high activity with only an ∼70 mV onset overpotential vs. RHE which is quite close to that of the com. 40% Pt/C catalyst, demonstrating the potential for the replacement of Pt-based catalysts. D. functional theory (DFT) calcns. indicated that the introduction of metal and nitrogen dopants can synergistically optimize the electronic structure of the CNTs and the adsorption free energy of H atoms on CNTs, and therefore promote the HER with a Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism.

Among the nonnoble-metal electrocatalysts for the H oxidn. reaction (HOR) in anion exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs), Ni-based nanoparticles showed the highest reported activities. We studied the chem. and electrochem. stability of representative Ni-based electrocatalysts. For this, C-supported monometallic Ni and bimetallic Ni3M (M = Co, Fe, Cu, Mo) nanoparticles were synthesized and tested using a set of complementary techniques. Mo suffers from intense dissoln. due to thermodn. instability. Cu was stable below 0.4 VRHE, though it undergoes noticeable electrochem. transient dissoln. if the potential range is extended to 0.5 VRHE and higher. However, Ni, Co, and Fe showed negligible dissoln. up to 0.7 VRHE. Despite the absence of dissoln., all catalysts lose their HOR activity if they are cycled to these high potentials. Physicochem. characterization of the aged catalysts revealed full oxidn. of the metal nanoparticles, which could be responsible for the performance deterioration. Although besides Ni3Mo, all studied materials show high stability under operating potentials of AEMFCs, if fuel starvation in AEMFCs results in high anodic potentials, cell activation and operation strategies are needed to prevent the passivation of the catalysts. These results present crit. insights toward the design and development of affordable Ni-based electrocatalysts for AEMFCs as well as provide a better understanding of the operation strategies for the stability of AEMFCs.

A review. Understanding and predicting materials corrosion under electrochem. environments are of increasing importance to both established and developing industries and technologies, including construction, marine materials, geol., and biomedicine, as well as to energy generation, storage, and conversion. Owing to recent progress in the accuracy and capability of d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. to describe the thermodn. stability of materials, this powerful computational tool can be used both to describe materials corrosion and to design materials with the desired corrosion resistance by using first-principles electrochem. phase diagrams. We review the progress in simulating electrochem. phase diagrams of bulk solids, surface systems, and point defects in materials using DFT methods as well as the application of these ab initio phase diagrams in realistic environments. We conclude by summarizing the remaining challenges in the thermodn. modeling of materials corrosion and promising future research directions.

Interest in anionic exchange membrane fuel cell (AEMFC) technol. has increased in recent years because of the possibility of using a variety of new catalyst materials in the alk. environment. Pt and Ni are popular base metal substrates for the development of highly active catalysts in many studies. However, for com. use, catalyst stability is paramount. In com. applications, such as back-up power systems, catalysts must tolerate high steady state potentials for extended periods of time. This could be detrimental to catalyst materials, esp. at the cathode. Yet, the stability of Pt and Ni in AEMFC environment is not fully understood under steady state potential. In this paper, the stabilities of Pt and Ni supported on carbon have been tested using a standby cell potential of 0.9 V, within an AEMFC environment. The study, combined with SEM, TEM, ICP-AES, and ICP-MS anal. results, shows significant morphol. changes in the supported Pt and Ni catalyst particles, as well as dissolved Pt and Ni in the AEM electrolyte with 0.14mgPt gAEM-1 and 0.2mgNi gAEM-1 after an one month test period. The Pt migration appears to be driven by the elec. field while Ni appears to show generic chem. diffusion.

A review. As substantial progress has been made in improving the performance of anion exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs) over the last decade, the durability of AEMFCs has become the most crit. requirement to deploy competitive energy conversion systems. Because of different operating environments from proton exchange membrane fuel cells, several AEMFC-specific component degrdns. have been identified as the limiting factors influencing the AEMFC durability. In this article, AEMFC durability protocol, the current status of AEMFC durability, and performance degrdn. mechanisms are reported based on the discussion during the US Department of Energy (DOE) Anion Exchange Membrane Workshop at Dallas, Texas, May 2019. With addnl. recent progress, we provide our perspectives on current tech. challenges and future action to develop long-lasting AEMFCs.

We report on the optimization of nickel-copper catalysts for superior performance as a cathode catalyst in anion exchange membrane (AEM) water electrolysis. The bifunctional system of NiCu mixed metal oxide (MMO) nanosheets includes Ni metallic, NiO, and CuO oxides provide rapid kinetics for the hydrogen-evolution reaction (HER) of the Volmer step. In-situ Raman spectroscopy for NiCu MMO proved that nickel hydroxide was sustained under HER conditions for at least 30,000 s, which may explain why the exceptional activity of NiCu MMO as compared to other nickel-copper catalysts is maintained over time. The activity of the NiCu MMO for the HER activity in alk. electrolytes increased as KOH concn. raised from 0.1 M to 1 M. The NiCu MMO nanosheets showed superior stability under alk. HER conditions for 30 h. The use of Nafion ionomer in the ink resulted in a higher HER c.d. as compared to inks with a Fumion anion ionomer. The max. HER performance was achieved at a Nafion ionomer to catalyst wt. ratio of 0.5. Using Ir black as the anode, the NiCu MMO cathode gave an AEM electrolyzer performance of 1.85 A/cm2 at 2 V in 1 M KOH at 50 °C. The NiCu MMO catalyst developed here delivers AEM performance comparable to PEM water electrolysis.

A Cu-Co-P electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) was designed with a dendritic and porous foam structure. Fabricated by one-step electrodeposition with binary alloy on a hydrogen bubble template, the porous foam exhibited remarkable HER activity in alk. conditions. Three-dimensional (3D) nanoporous nickel films were fabricated by a novel and facile method. The fabrication process involved the heat treatment of the electrodeposited zinc layer on nickel substrate and the subsequent electrochem. dealloying. The mutual diffusion of Ni and Zn during the heat treatment resulted in the formation of the Ni2Zn11 alloy surface film. The 3D nanoporous nickel films with open pores and interconnected ligaments were obtained by the electrochem. dealloying of relatively active zinc from the alloy surface film. As the electrodeposited zinc amt. increased, the thickness, pore diam. and pore d. of the nanoporous nickel films became larger. In our exptl. range, the thickest nanoporous nickel film presented a thickness of 8 μm and an av. pore diam. of 700 nm. The as-prepd. 3D nanoporous nickel films exhibited much higher electrocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) than smooth nickel foil, and their electrocatalytic activities for HER enhanced with increase in the porosity and thickness. It was concluded that the enhanced electrocatalytic activity and excellent electrochem. stability for HER of the as-prepd. 3D nanoporous nickel films can be ascribed to their unique nanostructured characteristics.

Ni and Ni/rGO were electrodeposited by galvanic square wave method with sonication. In contrast to smooth deposits of Ni, deposits of Ni/rGO had the cumulus/cauliflower type morphol. with developed surface. Herein, we introduce polymer nanofibers of
[email protected]
as interlayers into Li-S batteries. From 0 to 60°C, the interlayers can deliver high sulfur utilization, an outstanding rate capability, and excellent cycling life. High-temp. excitation makes it easier for the valence band electrons of TiO2 to transition to the conduction band. The electron-hole pairs formed on the surface combine with the ether group of 1,3-dioxolane in the electrolyte, which greatly reduces the decompn. and volatilization rates of the electrolyte, ensuring Li-S batteries with good cycle performance at high temps. The capacity can stabilize at 798.6 mA-h g-1 after 100 cycles at 60°C and 1C, and the battery can provide a capacity higher than 323.2 mA-h g-1 at 0°C. Simultaneously, the lithium metal sym. battery with a functional separator can be continuously cycled for 1800 and 750 h without a short circuit at the current densities of 0.65 and 1.63 mA cm-2, resp.

Herein, we describe an in-situ hybridization of Nickel Selenide (Ni3Se2) with a Nickel Foam (NF) current collector as an efficient, ultra-durable electrode for the continuous alk. water electrolysis. Earth abundant, cost effective, non-precious self-made Ni3Se2/NF electrode delivers an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) overpotential value of 315 mV at a c.d. of 100 mA cm-2 (vs. a reversible hydrogen electrode) in aq. electrolyte of 1 M KOH. On a static c.d. of 100 mA cm-2, Ni3Se2/NF electrode shows a good OER stability over 285 h with very small potential loss of 5.5% in alk. electrolyte. Accordingly, the alk. water electrolyzer constructed with Ni3Se2/NF (anode) and NiCo2S4/NF (cathode), it requires 1.58 V to deliver 10 mA cm-2 c.d., with 500 h continuous operation in 1 M KOH. In addn., we demonstrate that the light-driven water splitting using solar panel, it can be a promising approach to facilitate true independence from electricity in H2 fuel economy. Overall, this methodol. is one of the appropriate energy efficient ways to reduce the cost of water splitting devices, as it may simplify the diverse process and equipment.

In this paper, we report for the first time the fabrication of cauliflower-like Ni(OH)2 particles-coated fabrics with inverse special wettability via a facile hydrothermal method. The coated fabric is superhydrophilic in air and superoleophobic underwater, which can be changed into superhydrophobicity after being modified by long-chain fatty acid. After the superhydrophilic fabric is wetted by water in advance, hot alk. water can be removed from the light oil/water mixt. driven by gravity. Also, heavy oil can be removed from the heavy oil/hot alk. water mixt. under the action of gravity using superhydrophobic fabric. The sepn. efficiencies of the two fabrics for different mixts. of hot alk. water and light or heavy oil are more than 95.8%. Furthermore, a two-way sepn. device was designed via integrating a pair of fabrics with opposite wettability. The device can continuously sep. oil and water at the same time from oil/hot alk. water mixt. via one-step route with high sepn. efficiency without consideration of the d. of the oil. Moreover, the superhydrophilic fabric is capable of sepg. various oil-in-water emulsions. We believe that the as-prepd. fabrics and the designed device may find wide application in sepg. oil from alk. water.

One of the important challenges in alk. water electrolysis is to utilize a bifunctional catalyst for both hydrogen evolution (HER) and oxygen evolution (OER) reactions to increase the efficiency of water splitting devices for the long durable operations. Herein, nickel-cobalt-titanium (NCT) alloy is directly grown on a high corrosion resistance titanium foil by a simple, single, and rapid electrochem. deposition at room temp. The electrocatalytic activity of NCT alloy electrodes is evaluated for both HER and OER in aq. electrolyte. Our NCT electrocatalyst exhibits low overpotentials around 125 and 331 mV for HER and OER, resp., in 1 M KOH. In addn. to this outstanding activity, the bifunctional catalyst also exhibits excellent OER and HER electrode stability up to 150 h of continuous operation with a minimal loss in activity. Further, the NCT alloy directly grown on titanium foil is used to directly construct membrane electrode assembly (MEA) for alk. electrolyte membrane (AEM) water electrolyzer, which make the practical applicability. This single-step electrodeposition reveals NCT on titanium foil with high activity and excellent electrode stability suitable for replacing alternative com. viable catalyst for the alk. water splitting.

In this work, nickel-based electrodes were prepd. using composite electrodeposition technique in a nickel sulphamate bath contg. suspended micro- or nano-sized CeO2 particles. The prepd. Ni-CeO2 composite electrodes exhibit an enhanced high catalytic activity toward hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in alk. solns. X-ray diffraction patterns indicated that the CeO2 particles have been successfully incorporated into the Ni matrix and altered the texture coeff. (TC) of the Ni layer. The morphol. of the obtained coatings was characterized by SEM, and the CeO2 content was detd. by coupled energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry. The thermal stability of the composite electrodes was analyzed by thermogravimetric and differential scanning calorimetry, showing a good thermal stability. The catalytic activity of the composite electrodes for HER was measured by steady-state polarization and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy techniques in 1.0 M NaOH soln. at room temp. The exchange c.d. of HER on the Ni-CeO2 composite electrodes was much higher than that on Ni electrode. EIS results suggested that a synergetic effect on HER may exist between CeO2 particles and Ni matrix. Compared to nano-CeO2, the micro-CeO2 derived composite electrodes showed higher electrochem. activity. The possible correlation among particle size, content and catalytic activity is discussed.

Renewable alternative energy sources are required to decrease or eliminate the use of environmentally unfriendly fossil fuels. Hydrogen produced by electrolysis was identified as one such renewable energy carrier. In the current work, Ni nanoparticle (NP)-decorated multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) electrocatalyst cathodes are prepd. by a simple two-step procedure. MWCNTs are grown on stainless steel meshes by thermal-CVD (t-CVD) and then decorated with Ni NPs by pulsed laser ablation (PLA). The morphol. and electrochem. properties of the produced Ni NP/MWCNT cathodes were characterized through electron microscopy and linear Tafel polarization (LTP)/electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS), resp. SEM and TEM imaging revealed that the Ni NPs deposited by PLA are ∼4 nm in diam. with a narrow size distribution. The LTP measurements showed that the electrocatalytic activity of the Ni NP/MWCNT cathodes towards the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is dependent on PLA time and shows a max. at tPLA = 40 min. EIS measurements revealed that the HER response is characterized by a two time consts. process representing HER kinetics and adsorption of hydrogen.

The catalytic behavior of the catalysts was tested in the methane partial oxidn. reaction performed at 1 atm in a temp. range of 400-800 °C using dil. feed gas mixt. with CH4/O2 = 2 and gas hourly space velocity of 60,000 mL g-1 h-1. Total methane combustion was obsd. within the 450 °C ≤ T≤ 650 °C temp. range. Above 650 °C partial oxidn. of methane started to occur, reaching at 800 °C a CO selectivity close to 90%. The lanthanum contg. catalysts prepd. by wet impregnation exhibited higher CPO activity at lower temp. as compared to the co-pptd. ones. Opposite behavior was obsd. with the Ni-CeO2 catalysts. During the stability test at high temp., carbon formed only over the single oxide supported catalysts, Ni-CeO2 and Ni-La2O3. According to the characterization results carbon was not responsible for catalyst deactivation but it prevented the sintering of the nickel particle. The interplay of the crystallite sizes and the formation of various nickel-lanthanum oxide species with different Ni oxidn. states were responsible for the differences in the CPO performance.

Pure and mixed lanthanum and cerium oxides were synthesized via a reverse microemulsion-templated route. This approach yields highly homogeneous and phase-stable mixed oxides with high surface areas across the entire range of La:Ce ratios from pure lanthana to pure ceria. Surprisingly, all mixed oxides show the fluorite crystal structure of ceria, even for lanthanum contents as high as 90%. Varying the La:Ce ratio not only allows tailoring of the oxide morphol. (lattice parameter, pore structure, particle size, and surface area), but also results in a fine-tuning of the reducibility of the oxide which can be explained by the creation of oxygen vacancies in the ceria lattice upon La addn. Such finely controlled syntheses, which enable the formation of stable, homogeneous mixed oxides across the entire compn. range, open the path towards functional tailoring of oxide materials, such as rational catalyst design via fine-tuning of redox activity.

High gravimetric energy d., earth-abundance, and environmental friendliness of hydrogen sources have inspired the utilization of hydrogen fuel as a clean alternative to fossil fuels. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), a half reaction of water splitting, is crucial to the low-cost prodn. of pure H2 fuels but necessitates the use of electrocatalysts to expedite reaction kinetics. Owing to the availability of low-cost oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts for the counter electrode in alk. media and the lack of low-cost OER catalysts in acidic media, researchers have focused on developing HER catalysts in alk. media with high activity and stability. Nickel is well-known as an HER catalyst and continuous efforts have been undertaken to improve Ni-based catalysts as alk. electrolyzers. In this review, we summarize earlier studies of HER activity and mechanism on Ni surfaces, along with recent progress in the optimization of the Ni-based catalysts using various modern techniques. Recently developed Ni-based HER catalysts are categorized according to their chem. nature, and the advantages as well as limitations of each category are discussed. Among all Ni-based catalysts, Ni-based alloys and Ni-based hetero-structure exhibit the most promising electrocatalytic activity and stability owing to the fine-tuning of their surface adsorption properties via a synergistic nearby element or domain. Finally, selected applications of the developed Ni-based HER catalysts are highlighted, such as water splitting, the chloralkali process, and microbial electrolysis cell. Hybrid catalysts consisting of metal nanoparticles on a metal oxide support have emerged as a new class of catalysts that can improve various electrocatalytic reactions, but the origin of the improved performance is still unclear. Here we demonstrate that rationally designed hybrid catalysts through the in situ exsoln. process of metallic nanoparticles on a B-site Ni-substituted lead ruthenate pyrochlore oxide improve both oxygen evolution reaction and hydrogen evolution reaction activity. The effect of a redn. process with CO or H2 on the size of nickel particles in Ni/ZrO2 dry methane reforming catalysts have been studied by means of in situ x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy (DRIFTS). Our results clearly indicate that a high temp. treatment with CO increases the dispersion of the nickel metallic phase. XAS results have shown a lower coordination no. of Ni in the sample treated with CO than that reduced with H2. From the DRIFTS results, it can be established that, under the CO treatment, the formation of Ni(CO)4 complexes corrodes the nickel particles, decreasing their size. The formation of these gas mols. occurs without measurable losses of nickel from the catalyst which maintains the same nickel content after the hydrogen or the CO treatment at high temp. Therefore, this airborne nickel compd., by colliding with the zirconia surface, must deposit the nickel metal atoms around onto the support. This behavior is evidence of an important interaction between nickel and zirconia surface as unlike other supports there is no losses of nickel during the dispersion process on zirconia. Although different effects of CO on nickel catalysts have been previously described, we have found for the first time several exptl. evidences demonstrating the whole redispersion phenomenon.

All the X-ray spectra including X-ray diffraction, XPS and X-ray adsorption spectroscopy demonstrate that the cryst. phase structure, valence and coordination environment of hexagonal Ni2P are changed with increasing Co atoms. Electrochem. measurements show that the Co2-xNixP/CNT hybrids exhibit high activity and stability for the HER in acidic soln. The as-synthesized Co1.6Ni0.4P/CNT hybrid exhibits the highest electrocatalytic activity with low onset overpotential (36.1 mV), a small Tafel slope (46.7 mV dec-1), a much larger exchange c.d. (1.86 × 10-5 A cm-2), lower HER activation energy (57.3 kJ mol-1), and good stability. Such enhanced catalytic activity originates from the introduction of Co and strong synergistic effects between CNTs and Co2-xNixP. Meanwhile, d. functional theory calcns. also confirm that the higher HER catalytic activity of the Co2-xNixP/CNTs can be attributed to the splendid migratory aptitude of adsorbed single H atoms and the lower energy barrier for H2 formation after the introduction of Co atoms. The as-synthesized Co2-xNixP/CNT hybrid catalysts have great potential practical application in water splitting.

A facile and scalable spray pyrolysis process is applied to synthesize multi-shelled Ni-loaded yolk-shell catalysts on various supports (Al2O3, CeO2, ZrO2, and La(OH)3). The prepd. catalysts are applied to direct internal reforming (DIR) in a molten carbonate fuel cell (MCFC). Even on exposure to alkali hydroxide vapors, the Ni-loaded yolk-shell catalysts remain highly active for DIR-MCFCs. The
[email protected]
microspheres show the highest conversion (92%) of CH4 and the best stability among the prepd. Ni-loaded yolk-shell catalysts. Although the initial CH4 conversion of the
[email protected]
microspheres is higher than that of the
[email protected]
microspheres, the
[email protected]
microspheres are more stable. The catalytic performance is strongly dependent on the surface area and acidity and also partly dependent on the reducibility. The acidic nature of Al2O3 combined with its high surface area and yolk-shell structure enhances the adsorption of CH4 and resistance against alkali poisoning, resulting in efficient DIR-MCFC reactions.

Ni-based electrocatalysts for replacement of precious metal electrocatalyst, the cathode materials of anion exchange membrane water electrolyzer (AEMWE), are seriously unstable and low activity at hydrogen prodn. conditions. This study develops a high-performance, durable non-precious metal electrocatalyst for AEMWE, which show improved activity and durability. First, Ni/C was alloyed with Co and supported on carbon cloth coated with microporous carbon layer to improve the electrocatalytic activity of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalyst; then, oxide (Ni/Co-O) was locally formed on the synthesized NiCo/C to increase its activity and durability. Specifically, this oxide increased the coverage of OH- ions, formed hydrogen spillover channels, and promoted the HER. Further, its improved electrochem. durability was attributed to the high bond dissocn. energy of the metal oxide. The electrocatalyst was also evaluated as the cathode in single-cell (1-cell) and stack cell (5-cell) AEMWE systems to demonstrate that this superior performance would translate to the com. scale.

The application of electrocatalysts with high activity to a practical water electrolysis cell is a crucial challenge for the prodn. of pure hydrogen and commercialization of the water electrolyzer. Herein, a nanosized Cu0.5Co2.5O4 catalyst synthesized by co-pptn. by adjusting pH is applied to the anion exchange membrane water electrolysis (AEMWE) cell as an anode, which is demonstrated to have higher efficiency and stability than noble metal-based anodes. The compn. (Cu/Co) and morphol. of Cu0.5Co2.5O4 change as the pH increases and then nanoparticles are formed at pH 11, where oxygen vacancies are formed by the etching of Cu. In the d. functional theory study, the electronic structure of Co modified by Cu in the Co3O4 lattice leads to an optimal adsorption strength, resulting in a free energy diagram in which the potential of Cu0.5Co2.5O4 (1.756 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) is more thermodynamically favorable than that of Co3O4 (1.951 V vs. RHE). The Cu0.5Co2.5O4 catalyst has a recorded overpotential of 285 mV at 10 mA cm-2 in 1 M KOH. Furthermore, the AEMWE cell using Cu0.5Co2.5O4 as an anode exhibited a c.d. of 1.3 A cm-2 at 1.8 V, which is the highest performance among the reported papers and maintains around 80% energy conversion efficiency for 100 h.

Uniquely nanostructured CuCo2O4 is presented as an electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reactions (OER). CuCo2O4 particles in a chestnut-burr-like shape (CCO*, where * = chestnut burr) were hydrothermally synthesized around fibers of Ni foam substrates as current collectors. Chestnut burrs 4μm on av. had thorns consisting of less than five threads. Each thread was made of a consecutive array of nanobeads less than 10 nm. Nanovoids or nanopores were found between nanobeads. The chestnut-burr structure of CCO* allowed IrO2-overwhelming OER activity. By using the hierarchically nanostructured electrocatalyst directly grown on current collectors without binders and conducting agents, high performances of anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolysis was demonstrated. Three merits of the electrode architecture were emphasized. First, mass transfer pathways for reactants and products were secured in a microscale between thorns and in a nanoscale between nanobeads. Second, more active sites were exposed to electrolytes in the hierarchical structure. Third, direct growth of active materials on conductive substrates improved adhesion and elec. conduction. The unique structure of directly grown CCO* (CCO*, where* = chestnut burr) providing binder-free and conducting agent-free benefits and allowing exceptionally high loading on substrates dramatically enhanced electroactivities of OER for efficient electrolysis.

The innovation in highly efficient, stable, and economical bifunctional overall water-splitting electrocatalysts is crit. in developing sustainable energy, but it remains challenging. In this research, an unsophisticated method is developed to synthesize hybrid nanoparticles (FeN0.023/Mo2C/C) uniformly dispersed in nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets. Employing a low-cost and highly efficient electrocatalyst to replace Pt-based catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) has attracted increasing interest in renewable energy research. Earth-abundant transition metals such as Fe, Co and Ni have been investigated as promising alternatives in alk. electrolytes. However, these non-precious-metal catalysts are not stable in acids, excluding their application in the acidic solid polymer electrolyte (SPE). Herein, we report a strategy to encapsulate 3d transition metals Fe, Co and the FeCo alloy into nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and investigated their HER activity in acidic electrolytes. The optimized catalysts exhibited long-term durability and high activity with only an ∼70 mV onset overpotential vs. RHE which is quite close to that of the com. 40% Pt/C catalyst, demonstrating the potential for the replacement of Pt-based catalysts. D. functional theory (DFT) calcns. indicated that the introduction of metal and nitrogen dopants can synergistically optimize the electronic structure of the CNTs and the adsorption free energy of H atoms on CNTs, and therefore promote the HER with a Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism.

Among the nonnoble-metal electrocatalysts for the H oxidn. reaction (HOR) in anion exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs), Ni-based nanoparticles showed the highest reported activities. We studied the chem. and electrochem. stability of representative Ni-based electrocatalysts. For this, C-supported monometallic Ni and bimetallic Ni3M (M = Co, Fe, Cu, Mo) nanoparticles were synthesized and tested using a set of complementary techniques. Mo suffers from intense dissoln. due to thermodn. instability. Cu was stable below 0.4 VRHE, though it undergoes noticeable electrochem. transient dissoln. if the potential range is extended to 0.5 VRHE and higher. However, Ni, Co, and Fe showed negligible dissoln. up to 0.7 VRHE. Despite the absence of dissoln., all catalysts lose their HOR activity if they are cycled to these high potentials. Physicochem. characterization of the aged catalysts revealed full oxidn. of the metal nanoparticles, which could be responsible for the performance deterioration. Although besides Ni3Mo, all studied materials show high stability under operating potentials of AEMFCs, if fuel starvation in AEMFCs results in high anodic potentials, cell activation and operation strategies are needed to prevent the passivation of the catalysts. These results present crit. insights toward the design and development of affordable Ni-based electrocatalysts for AEMFCs as well as provide a better understanding of the operation strategies for the stability of AEMFCs.

A review. Understanding and predicting materials corrosion under electrochem. environments are of increasing importance to both established and developing industries and technologies, including construction, marine materials, geol., and biomedicine, as well as to energy generation, storage, and conversion. Owing to recent progress in the accuracy and capability of d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. to describe the thermodn. stability of materials, this powerful computational tool can be used both to describe materials corrosion and to design materials with the desired corrosion resistance by using first-principles electrochem. phase diagrams. We review the progress in simulating electrochem. phase diagrams of bulk solids, surface systems, and point defects in materials using DFT methods as well as the application of these ab initio phase diagrams in realistic environments. We conclude by summarizing the remaining challenges in the thermodn. modeling of materials corrosion and promising future research directions.

Interest in anionic exchange membrane fuel cell (AEMFC) technol. has increased in recent years because of the possibility of using a variety of new catalyst materials in the alk. environment. Pt and Ni are popular base metal substrates for the development of highly active catalysts in many studies. However, for com. use, catalyst stability is paramount. In com. applications, such as back-up power systems, catalysts must tolerate high steady state potentials for extended periods of time. This could be detrimental to catalyst materials, esp. at the cathode. Yet, the stability of Pt and Ni in AEMFC environment is not fully understood under steady state potential. In this paper, the stabilities of Pt and Ni supported on carbon have been tested using a standby cell potential of 0.9 V, within an AEMFC environment. The study, combined with SEM, TEM, ICP-AES, and ICP-MS anal. results, shows significant morphol. changes in the supported Pt and Ni catalyst particles, as well as dissolved Pt and Ni in the AEM electrolyte with 0.14mgPt gAEM-1 and 0.2mgNi gAEM-1 after an one month test period. The Pt migration appears to be driven by the elec. field while Ni appears to show generic chem. diffusion.

A review. As substantial progress has been made in improving the performance of anion exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs) over the last decade, the durability of AEMFCs has become the most crit. requirement to deploy competitive energy conversion systems. Because of different operating environments from proton exchange membrane fuel cells, several AEMFC-specific component degrdns. have been identified as the limiting factors influencing the AEMFC durability. In this article, AEMFC durability protocol, the current status of AEMFC durability, and performance degrdn. mechanisms are reported based on the discussion during the US Department of Energy (DOE) Anion Exchange Membrane Workshop at Dallas, Texas, May 2019. With addnl. recent progress, we provide our perspectives on current tech. challenges and future action to develop long-lasting AEMFCs.

We report on the optimization of nickel-copper catalysts for superior performance as a cathode catalyst in anion exchange membrane (AEM) water electrolysis. The bifunctional system of NiCu mixed metal oxide (MMO) nanosheets includes Ni metallic, NiO, and CuO oxides provide rapid kinetics for the hydrogen-evolution reaction (HER) of the Volmer step. In-situ Raman spectroscopy for NiCu MMO proved that nickel hydroxide was sustained under HER conditions for at least 30,000 s, which may explain why the exceptional activity of NiCu MMO as compared to other nickel-copper catalysts is maintained over time. The activity of the NiCu MMO for the HER activity in alk. electrolytes increased as KOH concn. raised from 0.1 M to 1 M. The NiCu MMO nanosheets showed superior stability under alk. HER conditions for 30 h. The use of Nafion ionomer in the ink resulted in a higher HER c.d. as compared to inks with a Fumion anion ionomer. The max. HER performance was achieved at a Nafion ionomer to catalyst wt. ratio of 0.5. Using Ir black as the anode, the NiCu MMO cathode gave an AEM electrolyzer performance of 1.85 A/cm2 at 2 V in 1 M KOH at 50 °C. The NiCu MMO catalyst developed here delivers AEM performance comparable to PEM water electrolysis.

Three-dimensional (3D) nanoporous nickel films were fabricated by a novel and facile method. The fabrication process involved the heat treatment of the electrodeposited zinc layer on nickel substrate and the subsequent electrochem. dealloying. The mutual diffusion of Ni and Zn during the heat treatment resulted in the formation of the Ni2Zn11 alloy surface film. The 3D nanoporous nickel films with open pores and interconnected ligaments were obtained by the electrochem. dealloying of relatively active zinc from the alloy surface film. As the electrodeposited zinc amt. increased, the thickness, pore diam. and pore d. of the nanoporous nickel films became larger. In our exptl. range, the thickest nanoporous nickel film presented a thickness of 8 μm and an av. pore diam. of 700 nm. The as-prepd. 3D nanoporous nickel films exhibited much higher electrocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) than smooth nickel foil, and their electrocatalytic activities for HER enhanced with increase in the porosity and thickness. It was concluded that the enhanced electrocatalytic activity and excellent electrochem. stability for HER of the as-prepd. 3D nanoporous nickel films can be ascribed to their unique nanostructured characteristics.

Herein, we describe an in-situ hybridization of Nickel Selenide (Ni3Se2) with a Nickel Foam (NF) current collector as an efficient, ultra-durable electrode for the continuous alk. water electrolysis. Earth abundant, cost effective, non-precious self-made Ni3Se2/NF electrode delivers an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) overpotential value of 315 mV at a c.d. of 100 mA cm-2 (vs. a reversible hydrogen electrode) in aq. electrolyte of 1 M KOH. On a static c.d. of 100 mA cm-2, Ni3Se2/NF electrode shows a good OER stability over 285 h with very small potential loss of 5.5% in alk. electrolyte. Accordingly, the alk. water electrolyzer constructed with Ni3Se2/NF (anode) and NiCo2S4/NF (cathode), it requires 1.58 V to deliver 10 mA cm-2 c.d., with 500 h continuous operation in 1 M KOH. In addn., we demonstrate that the light-driven water splitting using solar panel, it can be a promising approach to facilitate true independence from electricity in H2 fuel economy. Overall, this methodol. is one of the appropriate energy efficient ways to reduce the cost of water splitting devices, as it may simplify the diverse process and equipment.

In this paper, we report for the first time the fabrication of cauliflower-like Ni(OH)2 particles-coated fabrics with inverse special wettability via a facile hydrothermal method. The coated fabric is superhydrophilic in air and superoleophobic underwater, which can be changed into superhydrophobicity after being modified by long-chain fatty acid. After the superhydrophilic fabric is wetted by water in advance, hot alk. water can be removed from the light oil/water mixt. driven by gravity. Also, heavy oil can be removed from the heavy oil/hot alk. water mixt. under the action of gravity using superhydrophobic fabric. The sepn. efficiencies of the two fabrics for different mixts. of hot alk. water and light or heavy oil are more than 95.8%. Furthermore, a two-way sepn. device was designed via integrating a pair of fabrics with opposite wettability. The device can continuously sep. oil and water at the same time from oil/hot alk. water mixt. via one-step route with high sepn. efficiency without consideration of the d. of the oil. Moreover, the superhydrophilic fabric is capable of sepg. various oil-in-water emulsions. We believe that the as-prepd. fabrics and the designed device may find wide application in sepg. oil from alk. water.

One of the important challenges in alk. water electrolysis is to utilize a bifunctional catalyst for both hydrogen evolution (HER) and oxygen evolution (OER) reactions to increase the efficiency of water splitting devices for the long durable operations. Herein, nickel-cobalt-titanium (NCT) alloy is directly grown on a high corrosion resistance titanium foil by a simple, single, and rapid electrochem. deposition at room temp. The electrocatalytic activity of NCT alloy electrodes is evaluated for both HER and OER in aq. electrolyte. Our NCT electrocatalyst exhibits low overpotentials around 125 and 331 mV for HER and OER, resp., in 1 M KOH. In addn. to this outstanding activity, the bifunctional catalyst also exhibits excellent OER and HER electrode stability up to 150 h of continuous operation with a minimal loss in activity. Further, the NCT alloy directly grown on titanium foil is used to directly construct membrane electrode assembly (MEA) for alk. electrolyte membrane (AEM) water electrolyzer, which make the practical applicability. This single-step electrodeposition reveals NCT on titanium foil with high activity and excellent electrode stability suitable for replacing alternative com. viable catalyst for the alk. water splitting.

The morphol. of the obtained coatings was characterized by SEM, and the CeO2 content was detd. by coupled energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry. The thermal stability of the composite electrodes was analyzed by thermogravimetric and differential scanning calorimetry, showing a good thermal stability. The catalytic activity of the composite electrodes for HER was measured by steady-state polarization and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy techniques in 1.0 M NaOH soln. at room temp. The exchange c.d. of HER on the Ni-CeO2 composite electrodes was much higher than that on Ni electrode. EIS results suggested that a synergetic effect on HER may exist between CeO2 particles and Ni matrix. Compared to nano-CeO2, the micro-CeO2 derived composite electrodes showed higher electrochem. activity. The possible correlation among particle size, content and catalytic activity is discussed.

Renewable alternative energy sources are required to decrease or eliminate the use of environmentally unfriendly fossil fuels. Hydrogen produced by electrolysis was identified as one such renewable energy carrier. In the current work, Ni nanoparticle (NP)-decorated multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) electrocatalyst cathodes are prepd. by a simple two-step procedure. MWCNTs are grown on stainless steel meshes by thermal-CVD (t-CVD) and then decorated with Ni NPs by pulsed laser ablation (PLA). The morphol. and electrochem. properties of the produced Ni NP/MWCNT cathodes were characterized through electron microscopy and linear Tafel polarization (LTP)/electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS), resp. SEM and TEM imaging revealed that the Ni NPs deposited by PLA are ∼4 nm in diam. with a narrow size distribution. The LTP measurements showed that the electrocatalytic activity of the Ni NP/MWCNT cathodes towards the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is dependent on PLA time and shows a max. at tPLA = 40 min. EIS measurements revealed that the HER response is characterized by a two time consts. process representing HER kinetics and adsorption of hydrogen.

Pure and mixed lanthanum and cerium oxides were synthesized via a reverse microemulsion-templated route. This approach yields highly homogeneous and phase-stable mixed oxides with high surface areas across the entire range of La:Ce ratios from pure lanthana to pure ceria. Surprisingly, all mixed oxides show the fluorite crystal structure of ceria, even for lanthanum contents as high as 90%. Varying the La:Ce ratio not only allows tailoring of the oxide morphol. (lattice parameter, pore structure, particle size, and surface area), but also results in a fine-tuning of the reducibility of the oxide which can be explained by the creation of oxygen vacancies in the ceria lattice upon La addn. Such finely controlled syntheses, which enable the formation of stable, homogeneous mixed oxides across the entire compn. range, open the path towards functional tailoring of oxide materials, such as rational catalyst design via fine-tuning of redox activity.

High gravimetric energy d., earth-abundance, and environmental friendliness of hydrogen sources have inspired the utilization of hydrogen fuel as a clean alternative to fossil fuels. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), a half reaction of water splitting, is crucial to the low-cost prodn. of pure H2 fuels but necessitates the use of electrocatalysts to expedite reaction kinetics. Owing to the availability of low-cost oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts for the counter electrode in alk. media and the lack of low-cost OER catalysts in acidic media, researchers have focused on developing HER catalysts in alk. media with high activity and stability. Nickel is well-known as an HER catalyst and continuous efforts have been undertaken to improve Ni-based catalysts as alk. electrolyzers. In this review, we summarize earlier studies of HER activity and mechanism on Ni surfaces, along with recent progress in the optimization of the Ni-based catalysts using various modern techniques. Recently developed Ni-based HER catalysts are categorized according to their chem. nature, and the advantages as well as limitations of each category are discussed. Among all Ni-based catalysts, Ni-based alloys and Ni-based hetero-structure exhibit the most promising electrocatalytic activity and stability owing to the fine-tuning of their surface adsorption properties via a synergistic nearby element or domain. Finally, selected applications of the developed Ni-based HER catalysts are highlighted, such as water splitting, the chloralkali process, and microbial electrolysis cell. Hybrid catalysts consisting of metal nanoparticles on a metal oxide support have emerged as a new class of catalysts that can improve various electrocatalytic reactions, but the origin of the improved performance is still unclear. Here we demonstrate that rationally designed hybrid catalysts through the in situ exsoln. process of metallic nanoparticles on a B-site Ni-substituted lead ruthenate pyrochlore oxide improve both oxygen evolution reaction and hydrogen evolution reaction activity. A combination of operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy measurements and d. functional theory calcns. reveals that the generated oxygen and cation vacancies in the pyrochlore oxide support during the in situ exsoln. process can decrease the charge-transfer energy, thereby facilitating charge transfer between exsolved metal nanoparticles-oxide support as well as hybrid catalyst-electrolyte. These findings establish a structure-property relationship of complicated hybrid catalysts for efficient water splitting, suggesting a new strategy in designing various hybrid catalysts for other electrochem. reactions.

Electronic structure of nickel and palladium alloys. II. X-ray photoelectron core-level spectra
Hillebrecht, F. Ulrich; Fuggle, John C.; Bennett, Peter A.; Zolnierek, Zygmunt; Freiburg, C.

CODEN:

Measurements of the Ni 2p core levels in ∼30 alloys show a dependence of the satellite on the chem. environment, which for a given stoichiometry correlates with the electronegativity of the partner. In no case was a complete disappearance of the satellite obsd., which is interpreted as evidence for d-character in unoccupied states. The general view developed previously that despite the band filling there is no large charge transfer in Ni intermetallic compds., was confirmed by these observations. The band filling is a result of the mixing of wave functions which are centered on different sites. Studies of the satellite intensity as a function of stoichiometry in alloys with electropos. metals show the satellite to weaken as long as the band is being filled, and then to reach an almost const. intensity at some partner-element concn. It is not possible to ext. similar information from the spectra of Pd compds. because the satellites are weaker and partially obscured by inelastic losses.

Modifying the Size of Nickel Metallic Particles by H2/CO Treatment in Ni/ZrO2 Methane Dry Reforming Catalysts
Gonzalez-Delacruz, Victor M.; Pereniguez, Rosa; Ternero, Fatima; Holgado, Juan P.; Caballero, Alfonso
ACS Catalysis
(
2011
),
1
(
2
),
82-88
CODEN:

; ISSN:
2155-5435
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The effect of a redn. process with CO or H2 on the size of nickel particles in Ni/ZrO2 dry methane reforming catalysts have been studied by means of in situ x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy (DRIFTS). Our results clearly indicate that a high temp. treatment with CO increases the dispersion of the nickel metallic phase. XAS results have shown a lower coordination no. of Ni in the sample treated with CO than that reduced with H2. From the DRIFTS results, it can be established that, under the CO treatment, the formation of Ni(CO)4 complexes corrodes the nickel particles, decreasing their size. The formation of these gas mols. occurs without measurable losses of nickel from the catalyst which maintains the same nickel content after the hydrogen or the CO treatment at high temp. Therefore, this airborne nickel compd., by colliding with the zirconia surface, must deposit the nickel metal atoms around onto the support. This behavior is evidence of an important interaction between nickel and zirconia surface as unlike other supports there is no losses of nickel during the dispersion process on zirconia. Although different effects of CO on nickel catalysts have been previously described, we have found for the first time several exptl. evidences demonstrating the whole redispersion phenomenon.

Cobalt nickel phosphide nanoparticles decorated carbon nanotubes as advanced hybrid catalysts for hydrogen evolution
Pan, Yuan; Chen, Yinjuan; Lin, Yan; Cui, Peixin; Sun, Kaian; Liu, Yunqi; Liu, Chenguang
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability
(

),

(

CODEN:

2050-7496
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Exploring new hybrid catalysts to replace Pt-based catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is important for various renewable energy applications. However, the design and synthesis of such catalysts are still challenging. Herein, we focus on the development of a series of hybrid materials consisting of cobalt nickel phosphide nanoparticles (NPs) decorated carbon nanotubes (Co2-xNixP/CNTs) as efficient catalysts for enhanced HER catalytic activity. All the X-ray spectra including X-ray diffraction, XPS and X-ray adsorption spectroscopy demonstrate that the cryst. phase structure, valence and coordination environment of hexagonal Ni2P are changed with increasing Co atoms. Electrochem. measurements show that the Co2-xNixP/CNT hybrids exhibit high activity and stability for the HER in acidic soln. The as-synthesized Co1.6Ni0.4P/CNT hybrid exhibits the highest electrocatalytic activity with low onset overpotential (36.1 mV), a small Tafel slope (46.7 mV dec-1), a much larger exchange c.d. (1.86 × 10-5 A cm-2), lower HER activation energy (57.3 kJ mol-1), and good stability. Such enhanced catalytic activity originates from the introduction of Co and strong synergistic effects between CNTs and Co2-xNixP. Meanwhile, d. functional theory calcns. also confirm that the higher HER catalytic activity of the Co2-xNixP/CNTs can be attributed to the splendid migratory aptitude of adsorbed single H atoms and the lower energy barrier for H2 formation after the introduction of Co atoms. The as-synthesized Co2-xNixP/CNT hybrid catalysts have great potential practical application in water splitting.

A facile and scalable spray pyrolysis process is applied to synthesize multi-shelled Ni-loaded yolk-shell catalysts on various supports (Al2O3, CeO2, ZrO2, and La(OH)3). The prepd. catalysts are applied to direct internal reforming (DIR) in a molten carbonate fuel cell (MCFC). Even on exposure to alkali hydroxide vapors, the Ni-loaded yolk-shell catalysts remain highly active for DIR-MCFCs. The
[email protected]
microspheres show the highest conversion (92%) of CH4 and the best stability among the prepd. Ni-loaded yolk-shell catalysts. Although the initial CH4 conversion of the
[email protected]
microspheres is higher than that of the
[email protected]
microspheres, the
[email protected]
microspheres are more stable. The catalytic performance is strongly dependent on the surface area and acidity and also partly dependent on the reducibility. The acidic nature of Al2O3 combined with its high surface area and yolk-shell structure enhances the adsorption of CH4 and resistance against alkali poisoning, resulting in efficient DIR-MCFC reactions.
